newsitem.title: CANADA: New twists fail to clarify Bre-X saga.
newsitem.headline: New twists fail to clarify Bre-X saga.

text.p: Fresh twists in the Bre-X Minerals Ltd. saga on Monday failed to clear the fog of uncertainty that has enveloped the troubled Canadian gold exploration company since last week.

Bre-X has been under fire since test results from partner Freeport-McMoRan Copper & Gold Inc. last week called into question Bre-X's claim that the Busang property in the jungles of Borneo was possibly the biggest gold find this century.
Disgruntled shareholders went on the warpath. A group in the United States filed a class action lawsuit in Texas on Friday, Houston-based law firm Baker & Botts said on Monday.

"Basically it's a class-action on behalf of Bre-X shareholders who have been injured in buying or selling the stock over the last three or four years," Paul Yetter, a lawyer with Baker & Botts, said in a telephone interview.

"Beginning in 1994 defendants convinced the world that Bre-X owned 90 percent of a massive gold deposit, perhaps the largest ever discovered, located in the Busang area of East Kalimantan, Indonesia. This was false," the plaintiffs alleged in the suit, which named Bre-X and its chief executive David Walsh among the defendants.
"Indeed it now appears that a multi-billion dollar fraud may have been perpetrated on the investing public," they said in court papers.

Bre-X, clearly on the defensive, issued a statement on Monday urging the Toronto Stock Exchange to keep trading in its shares halted until after Freeport completed its due diligence study and Strathcona Minerals, Bre-X's independent consultant, finished an audit of earlier drilling results.
Bre-X also said it would review recent statements about the company and might consider legal action if warranted against those who, the company said, were spreading "misinformation".

On Thursday, panicked sellers slashed almost C$3 billion ($2.19 billion) off Bre-X's share price when the TSE ignored the company's initial request to postpone trading for several weeks, and re-opened trading late in the session.

The TSE on Thursday stood by its decision to resume trading in the stock, saying its task was to provide a continuous market in securities for investors. It said the audit could take many weeks to complete.
"The exchange does not believe that it is appropriate to deprive shareholders and investors of a market for such a lengthy period of time," the TSE said in a rare explanatory statement.
It appeared that the TSE planned to turn a deaf ear to Bre-X's latest request for a prolonged trading halt.
The exchange, Canada's biggest, said in a statement on Monday that it would resume trading in the stock on Tuesday after engineering firm Kilborn SNC-Lavalin issued a release.
The stock was halted all day on Monday. Bre-X closed at C$2.50 in Toronto last Thursday, down C$13.
